exercises.setup_notes: Position the barbell on your upper traps.
exercises.execution_notes: Lock in your bar path, squat down deep, and stand back up.
exercises.tier_reasons: High quad tension, feels good, excellent for progressive overload.
exercises.targeted_muscle_parts: All heads, with less emphasis on rectus femoris.
exercises.scientific_insights: Studies show solid rectus femoris growth despite anatomical concerns.
exercises.additional_notes: Include another exercise to fully engage rectus femoris.
exercises.selection_reason: The Barbell Back Squat is a fundamental compound exercise that effectively targets the quadriceps, aligning with the user's goal of defined quadriceps. It allows for progressive overload, which is crucial for muscle growth, and fits well within an intermediate workout plan.

exercises.setup_notes: Sit on the ground with your upper back against a bench and a barbell over your hips.
exercises.execution_notes: Drive through your heels to lift your hips until they are fully extended, keeping a neutral pelvis.
exercises.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the upper glutes due to the position of the hips in full extension.
exercises.scientific_insights: A 2016 study by Contreras et al. found the barbell hip thrust resulted in the greatest upper glute activity.
exercises.additional_notes: A neutral pelvic position is recommended for optimal glute activation.
exercises.alternative_exercises: American Hip Thrust, Banded Hip Thrust
exercises.selection_reason: The Barbell Hip Thrust is excellent for targeting the glutes, particularly the upper glutes, which aligns with the user's goal of rounded glutes. It is a staple exercise for glute development and fits well within an intermediate workout plan.

exercises.setup_notes: Start with the bar on the ground. Pick it up like a regular deadlift for the first rep.
exercises.execution_notes: Keep the chest up, push hips back, and keep knees back. Lower slowly and maintain tension on the hamstrings. Do not let the weight rest on the ground.
exercises.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets the hamstrings and glutes due to the hip hinge movement.
exercises.additional_notes: Ensure to maintain proper form to avoid lower back strain.
exercises.selection_reason: The Romanian Deadlift is a key exercise for targeting the hamstrings and glutes, aligning with the user's goal of developing these muscle groups. It is effective for building strength and muscle mass in the posterior chain, suitable for an intermediate fitness level.

exercises.setup_notes: Position one foot on a bench behind you.
exercises.execution_notes: Squat down with the front leg, keeping the torso upright.
exercises.targeted_muscle_parts: All heads, with emphasis on vastus medialis and lateralis.
exercises.additional_notes: Limit to two sets per workout due to fatigue.
exercises.selection_reason: The Bulgarian Split Squat is a unilateral exercise that effectively targets the quadriceps, providing a high stretch and engagement of the vastus medialis and lateralis. It also offers balance and stability benefits, making it a great addition to an intermediate workout plan.

exercises.setup_notes: Use a barbell, similar to a conventional deadlift setup.
exercises.execution_notes: Keep hips high and knees more straight. Hinge at the hips to initiate the pull.
exercises.targeted_muscle_parts: Focuses on the hamstrings due to the hip hinge movement.
exercises.limitations: Can be awkward for beginners; start light.
exercises.additional_notes: Do not push too close to failure until comfortable with the technique.
exercises.selection_reason: The Stiff-Legged Deadlift is an excellent exercise for targeting the hamstrings and glutes, focusing on the hip hinge movement. It complements the Romanian Deadlift and provides variety in targeting the posterior chain, suitable for an intermediate fitness level.

warmup_exercises.execution_notes: Perform squats with a controlled motion, focusing on depth and form.

warmup_exercises.setup_notes: Stand next to a wall for support.
warmup_exercises.execution_notes: Swing one leg forward and backward, then side to side.
Rotate hips in a circular motion, first clockwise, then counterclockwise.
